WRITING.TEXT:
*thats exactly what ive done here*
Except you **DIDN'T SAY** were "averages". That was literally the extent of my entire complaint - the information isn't implicitly wrong, but if you don't mention that these figures aren't absolute, stupid YouTubers are going to take them at face-value and not know enough to negotiate - and that is very dangerous.
*because 99% of the time your email will be ignored or you are forwarded to basic contract.*
Are you just pulling this number out of your ass? I've spoken with at least 12 separate MCNs over the years, and have never had any issue communicating with any of them. Every one of my YouTube peers has similar stories - e-mails, phone calls, contracts - negotiating is the norm in this space, not some rare specialty reserved for the elite. You criticized me earlier for using anecdotal evidence, but you're much more guilty of it here. Just because *you're* ignored doesn't mean everyone else will be.
Your also assuming that every person can negotiate a contract or does speak English
No, I'm not assuming that at all. I'm just saying -- your article needs to allow the reader to MAKE THEIR OWN CONCLUSIONS, and mention that these numbers **are not fixed**.

sure you can negotiate most of the stuff
That was my point! Just include that in the article! Or, at that very least, mention that your figures are only *averages* and not set numbers.
YouTubers NEED TO BE ENCOURAGED TO NEGOTIATE! It's really dangerous, and ignorant to simply take every contract at face value without ever trying to tailor it to your own needs.
And, regarding Maker Gen - is that not a separate sub-group of Maker? Shouldn't they both be listed? If you're only listing one... Why not the parent company?
Don't really have one, haha. I've produced 15 separate shows across four channels over ten years. A little but of everything.

Straight to the ad hominem attacks, huh? What's your problem?
My critiques were valid. They're not based on anecdotes, and have nothing to do with my viewership or time on the site. Your article was, very simply, factually incorrect - if only, by omission.

I noticed like halfway through my 3rd-watch-through :-)
It's prevalent in all the series, but I felt like Voyager was the worst offender.
I commented on *his* post. I think he knows, haha.
Check out the video description for a BTS photo album.
The "channel watermark". It's under CHANNEL BRANDING.

Any "enhancements" you'd employ would best be added in your NLE, anyway - rather than at the point-of-recording (as you have zero flexibility in post).
As always - whatever works for you is just fine.
Take it from me, someone who's made this decision years ago: **stick to one channel**.

From the sidebar -- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=slgldWAsB0M
Everything you need to know about the system.
https://support.google.com/adsense/answer/7164703?hl=en

... but most of this stuff is negotiable. And what's worse: you don't explicitly mention that. The information here is dangerously limited. It's going to give people that don't know any better the impression that MCNs *only* do "X" - when that isn't the case at all.
*(And why do you have Maker GEN, but not 'Maker'?)*
And for fuck's sake, capitalize your **I**'s.

* Couldn't mention the cubs winning the world series?*
To be fair, the article was written before they won.
A couple episodes have EIGHT!
Shh... don't tell him. You'd ruin his fun.
Pretty sure Chakotay is the worst (regular) character in all of Star Trek. His "vision quests" are routinely the low-points of the entire series.
Mine, too.
I haven't, no. But every single instance is in that video, so it shouldn't be too hard to compile.
I'm glad you noticed that! The grouping / arrangement was probably the trickiest part.
Janeway can just say, "It's a leather jacket". The "some kind of leather jacket" is just useless and redundant.
"Leather jacket" is my personal favorite. That episode, "The 37s" also has a series-most eight instances of the phrase.
I appreciate that, thank you.
"Like pants"... Haha, what?
Is it still a "good catch" when you made the mistake in the first place? Haha.
Thank you :-)
I'm sorry, what? The clips aren't chronical, and outnumber the episodes by 2:1.
Just a typo - I make them frequently in Premiere, and rarely catch all of them. Especially with such a large project like this.
The count is correct. 24 is just mis-labeled.

The word you're looking for is *intensity*.
Voyager is more fun, but DS9 is better written. Depends on my mood, but I love them both.
.#23 is listed twice, as well. Nobody's perfect ;-)
Ah... didn't know this - thank you.

I have an i7 X980 3.33 Ghz, and 12GB of RAM as well - glad to hear it works on medium at least. I'm surprised a computer built back in 2009/2010 can play a brand new game like this at all - but since I can't quite afford another upgrade yet...

WRITING.TITLE: Is Planet Coaster playable with (only) a 1.5gb GTX 580 graphics card?
WRITING.TEXT:
Every other part of my 7-year-old computer meets the recommended requirements, but my aging GPU doesn't meet the 'Minimum'. Could I still play Planet Coaster on reduced settings, or am I shit-out-luck? Didn't know the game existing until two days ago, otherwise I would have tried testing during Beta!
Appreciate any help :-)

Seems we are both correct. See my other post here.
Huh. I've dealt with some 2,000+ claims, and never seen them broken-apart like that. In that case, you'd have to appeal both. But, you get 3-at-a-time, so good luck.
YouTube [doesn't give you the option](https://gyazo.com/299d44d1d1dab72f58c680b3a17e4107) to appeal multiple claims on the same asset individually - so **both would get removed if you win**.

*each claim counts as separate unit*
Incorrect.

Normally I wouldn't point it out- but it's one of those word-swap-mistakes that some people genuinely don't know they've made. I mispronounced "wreak havoc" as "wreck havoc" for years until someone corrected me, haha.

At 18 years old, when filling out a profile for college dormitory preferences, I check-off a single box to be placed on the "technology" floor.
If not for that decision, I would not have met my wife, or ended up friends and business-partners with Jory Caron, and the beginning of my YouTube career / "Is It A Good Idea To Microwave This?" would never have been. Plus, I have three separate life-long friendships from that first freshman rooming arrangement.
I'm 30 now, and nearly every thing I hold dear in my life can be traced back to that single decision. If not for that housing-choice, I'd not have those friends/career, and my life would be drastically different.

As far as AdSense is concerned, you haven't reached the threshold yet, because October's earnings don't process until 20+ days after the end of the month.
You'll see November's money around Christmas, etc.

Asides from making sure your YouTube is correctly connected to AdSense - don't pay attention to it, like ever. Since 2012, they disconnected all of the reporting info, so now it is effectively useless. The "$0 earnings" is common, ignore it.
If your analytics said you made $200, you'll get that $200 about three weeks after the end of the month it was earned in.

Yeah, Google AdSense (no such thing as YouTube AdSense) stopped reporting on YouTube earnings like four years ago. You only get info on "most recent" payment now - every other field will show $0. The platform is effectively useless for YouTubers.
You will be paid ~25 days after the end of the first month you cross $100 threshold. So, keep an eye out for your cash around Thanksgiving.

Hard to believe that catchy ["They'll never stop The Simpsons"](https://youtu.be/e0PJYqzht3s) clip-show song aired way back in 2002. More than half of the shows 600 episodes have aired since. When they said, "we've got stories for years" - they meant it!
Looks awesome. Sarcastic / arrogant Batman is best Batman. I see this breaking $500 worldwide million easily.
Oh, that's right. I meant the other guy, David Strathairn.
When they killed Solomon, and (mostly) wrapped up the whole Kabal plot line. That's when it went downhill for me. To be fair, seasons 1 and 2 weren't excellent either.
I don't think any email arrangement, save for openly racist/vile screen names are automatically disqualifying. But, in addition to other items, an @aol addresses can definitely be a red flag.
And honestly, if someone refuses to do business (or reach out to initiate) solely based on you using a Gmail address? They're not worth it, IMO. @aol.com however, is another story :-)

Honestly, if you lose a potential client / contact over something as trivial as the prefix to your domain's e-mail address - they probably aren't worth doing business with anyway.
Unless of course your e-mail is name@aol.com - that's just foolish ;-)
I'm a professional YouTuber. No true 'human' clients - just the platform itself.

Well, US Copyright Law doesn't really have a classification for that type of material yet. But, that aside - a collaborate revenue share for fringe-works like that would be pretty cool.
I remember talking to a YouTube engineer / rep at VidCon a few years back and they mentioned they wanted to begin offering YouTubers the ability to split revenue between multiple people, on a per-video basis, for collab-videos, etc. Unfortunately, and obviously, nothing ever came of it.

Well, my wife is going to love this news. Haha.
Still though, I'd prefer someone younger, less-known. Allow him to really play the character for many, many years. I fear Hardy is already much too established / famous to sign a contract beyond three films. Like Craig, he'll want to shop around and try other projects. Maybe it's selfish of me, but I want to see an actor that sticks almost-exclusively to Bond for a nice 7+ picture deal.
But hey, Disney managed to get Robert Downey to do that many Marvel films, so maybe an arrangement like that is possible with Hardy. Did seem like his recent project-choices were gravitating towards heavier, Oscar-worthy roles (Child 44, Legend, etc.). I doubt he'll get any consideration as 007. Plus - if he's going to be the star of any franchise, I'd prefer it was "Mad Max". That series so much going for it right now.
Neat. I like this analogy.
The 'official' ones often are, yes :-)
Nice! Been far too long since I've seen Quantum Leap. Wonderful show.
Seems like an inordinately convenient theory!

Realistically, I don't know that the holodecks couldn't have inhabitable space larger than the original room itself. Vic Fontaine's Vegas showroom is a great example of what I believe would be its "true" limitations. Or, a bridge-simulation: all action takes place in a confined place.
How does it account for movement across a distance greater than the room itself? Are their mini treadmill like devices keeping our characters in place? With forcefields, etc - such a setup is possible, but I'm curious how that'd look.
You sound very sure of this - is this explanation from an official or non-canon source somewhere? Never heard the "tractor beam" bit before.
Little personal cylinders, huh? Not a bad concept! I want to see someone draw a sketch of what this might look like now, haha. Good theory!

WRITING.TITLE: How do holodecks/suites work when multiple people occupy a space larger than the holo-room itself? Eg: "Take Me Out To The Holosuite"
WRITING.TEXT:
In that s7 episode of DS9, there are at least 20 live-bodies occupying a baseball field-sized holo-environment, all running around and playing baseball. But the holosuites at Quark's are, at best - 50 feet across at their widest.
For a single individual, the emitters would continually update the surroundings based on the player's position - but how would it work when there's two or more people spread over large distances?
Looking forward to hearing some of your theories!

What you're describing is just a monetize-claim. The name of the claim-type refers to what the CLAIMANT is doing with the content, not you, haha :-)
So, when they place a monetize claim, that means you can't.

Eh... I disagree. If I review a movie, why should I have to share my revenue with Universal Studios? Owning this content, and retaining monetization from it is sort of the ENTIRE point of fair use law.

Track also demonetizes the video.
Not sure where you've heard this, but it does not. Sort of defeats the ENTIRE purpose of that option, actually. A "track" claim is extremely rare though - I don't know if I've ever got one myself (out of the 2,000+ claims I've received) - and my CMS has never issued one, either.
Indeed you did. I also posted this thread here on Reddit (unsure if you noticed that).
Yeah, that sounds familiar. My trailer reviews are very disproportionately claimed, and rejected.
Sensitivity isn't always a good thing with mics - but yeah, it's marketing, for sure. It's popular... because it's popular - not because it's the best. And certainly not at that price range.
Appreciate it man, thank you very much! Nice to e-meet an old fan!

So, you only appeal one at a time? I used to to that until I had like 100 at once, and I was just like, "fuck it - this is taking too long". Now, I try to never have LESS than three at once. The odds of all three coming back negative are virtually non-existant, anyway. I'm very confident in my content being "fair use", which helps. Yours is too, though - for that matter.

Precisely what it sounds like - the claimant merely tracks the progress / analytics of your content. Very rarely implemented, but it exists. If you're interested in learning more about Content ID - I highly suggest watching the video I did on the subject that's permanently linked in this SubReddit's sidebar - will teach you everything you need to know :-)

Great question, Jay! (I should have known the most well-thought-out question would come from you, haha).
Honestly, no idea. Best case scenario: it works exactly the same as the dispute-level; wherein you have 5 days after the rejection to re-initiate the process with an appeal to keep the funds in escrow. Worse case scenario: the user doesn't get any revenue until after the entire thing is awarded in their favor with a successful appeal or counter-notification.
On the plus side however, by virtue of the lengthy process itself, any lost-appeals will likely have come after a video has already seen its peak 'earnings window', so lost revenue in this scenario is likely to be much lower than a video during its first days of being uploaded. Plus, if YouTube claims only 1% of videos are disputed, I have to imagine the amount that gets appealed are probably 1% of that. And speaking anecdotally, my experience bears-out that maybe 1 out of every 5 disputes I make is rejected.

Ignoring the fact that "copyright trolls" are EXTREMELY rare - it's doubtful. Because you can dispute the strikes, too - and as soon as you begin that process (even five days late) - that revenue is now held in escrow.
It would be awarded to the claimant, assuming they issued a "monetize" policy, and not track or block.
Well, they're definitely two different things, but claims LEAD to strikes, so they're also very connected, as well.
Prior to 2014, yes - this was the case.

I believe you'd lose the revenue for all eight days it was claimed, where you didn't take action.
Which begs the question - unless you were off-grid for a week+, why would you wait so long to file a dispute? The process only takes about 30 seconds.

What my problem is here is youtube is lowering all my video volumes.
I can 100% guarantee that is NOT your "problem". I've never used Vegas, so I can't speak to its specific toolset. But based on our conversation so far, it seems like you don't completely understand what you're doing - and more than likely, THAT is the cause of your issue.
Like I said, watch some tutorials, learn how your program works, and how to correctly output your videos using YouTube's recommended encoding settings.
Those two things are intrinsically linked, so I'm confused by your confusion. If you get a "false strike", you would dispute it - and now, the money earning during arbitration is held in escrow.
To be fair, since 2014 ad-revenue was disabled entirely during arbitration - so it hasn't been advantageous for "trolls" for several years now. Moreover, what you're describing is EXTREMELY rare.
... Well, this is that. We don't need any more "help".

You want your final master audio mix (the meters on the far right) to register -3Db. Not 30. And not the slider control, the actual audio needs to peak there.
I suggest you watch some tutorials on Vegas, audio mixing and basic NLE controls. You seem, no offense, woefully I'll equipped at the moment.

Not sure you're getting me, or maybe you just need more help learning your NLE?
You need to have your FINAL mix average at -3 Db. Lowering the volume of a single track down 3 decibels is literally doing the exact opposite of that.
Am I making sense?

You must not have been around *before* annotations. Because when they came out, it was one of the coolest and most innovative features YouTube ever created. The things people were able to do in those early months/years with them were INCREDIBLE. Fantastic tool - I only wish they maintained a uniform look on all devices - but mobile never supported them :(
The newer "info icon" thing is a decent middle-ground though.
The few times I've done this - the entire channel was suspended within a day. That was a number of years ago, so not sure if the timeline/process has changed. Good luck to you - this stuff SUCKS.

Mix your audio to -3 Db.
That's it.

It's too bad you didn't visit this sub first - I always try to steer people away from the Blue mics. Way overpriced for their quality. Although to be fair - you probably did visit this sub, because people love those stupid Blue products for some reason.
Great question. Best way would be to check the CSV / downloadable reports for that time period. Those are most accurate revenue figures.

WRITING.TITLE: The Content ID "escrow" fix finally goes live today! System is now virtually 100% reliable for end-users.

WRITING.TEXT: ... And I was right. Two months later, and this is a total non issue.

"Horribly unfunny"
When was the last time you actually watched the show regularly?

You should try watching the show again with an open mind. Instead of, like, condemning two decades of quality television based on a single graph. The show might not be AS good as its golden era, but that doesn't mean it's bad.

Yeh, there are always a lot of edits. All hidden beneath the b-roll, but they're there.
That said, I have a LOT of experience, both professional and otherwise. Did 4 years as a radio DJ, I've taken public speaking courses - and have been making video content for over 16 years. Like I said, it just takes practice :-)

1) I do! At least, for certain shows like "Movie Night". But I have no idea how many others do. I would guess that,
2) The large majority do not, especially any instance where a video has multiple hosts, like a podcast setting - but it depends on the type of content.
3) Practice, research, and confidence.
So, here's an example of "scripted", https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wq9WGpWwUBc
And here's when I'm not on script, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aVeXpTWPdHc
Hopefully this helps somewhat?

People see one high-profile instance like the one OP posted about (which again, was a practical non-issue that could have been cleared up in 30 seconds) - and assume the entire system is broken and corrupt. Or that YouTube has some corporate bias, when they're not even involved in the process at all.

I don't think these minor inconveniences are emblematic of the negative situation OP suggested in his so-called current state of YouTube.
Sure, the occasional match claim occurs, or even rarer are situations like yours where it's a completely misidentified match - but in all instances, it takes a user just 30 seconds to initiate the risk-free dispute process and instantly restore their video's visibility and monetization on the site.
"Luck" had nothing to do with it. The system is EXTREMELY reliable. In fact, to date - out of the billions and billions of videos upload, there hasn't been a single reported case of someone losing all three steps of the dispute-appeal-counter notification process unjustly. And indeed, it appears you only needed the first of the three steps to correctly restore your content. Anecdotally, of the 2,000+ claims I've received on my movie reviews... only 150 or so have made it to 'appeal', and only 2 required a counter-notification to be overturned. My win-rate is still 100% for all 2,000.
For what it's able to do - on such a large scale, the Content ID system isn't good - it's incredible.

It's almost like you went out of your way to find the shittest-quality possible, when this version is available with a 2-second Google search, http://bit.ly/2dTuQWa
And what makes it a "mobile wallpaper", exactly? Literally any image can be - especially since most phones let you position/crop right there as you apply it.
Sorry, I'm just confused by this entire thing.
*Issued a Content ID block claim
It'a a risk-free process that takes less than 30 seconds to complete, actually.

No, certainly not. But again, it suggests you didn't dispute the claim. And since you've avoided answering my question, I'm inclined to believe my assumption was correct.
Especially since in YOUR OWN image, the "file a dispute" option is unclicked. But please, instead of downvoting, tell me I'm wrong.
... well, have you? Seems like you wouldn't have posted here if you had bothered.
Awesome, thanks man! Best of luck to you, This video is a great start.

**Why haven't you disputed the Content ID claim?**
(In your own image, the "file a dispute" option is un-clicked)

poster boy for Bad Fathering Magazine
hahahah

I don't feel "nonchalant" because it's "so common". I'm nonchalant because it's not an issue at all. Content ID works *extremely* well, as this occasional issue is but a minor inconvenience to the end-user, which most people never have to deal with personally.
YouTube's current state, vis a vis Content ID is great. OP was suggesting otherwise, and I take issue with people ignoring facts and truth in favor of ignorant vilification.

I did the opposite, and took a cross-country road trip on my way back from college. Me, and my three buddies did Los Angeles Boston the week before our graduation (we were doing a semester in LA, whereas normal campus was in Boston). An incredible experience that cemented my love of road trips.
Done over 20,000 miles around this country in the eight years since on five other major road trips. I've video/vlogged most of them too! - https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLn6LLHbJqY-i7zTwV1191hL1gc78XIsEA
Solid video! I'm glad you included some of yourself in here! Most of the stuff I see on here is just impersonal montages with music-only. Thanks for sharing :-)
